trans-unit.source: Deploy and manage backup for Azure VMs using PowerShell | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Deploy and manage backup for Azure VMs using PowerShell | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to deploy and manage Azure Backup using PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Learn how to deploy and manage Azure Backup using PowerShell

trans-unit.source: This article shows you how to use Azure PowerShell for backup and recovery of Azure IaaS VMs.
trans-unit.target: This article shows you how to use Azure PowerShell for backup and recovery of Azure IaaS VMs.

trans-unit.source: Get <linkText>introduced to Azure IaaS VM backup</linkText><title></title> in the Azure Backup documentation.
trans-unit.target: Get <linkText>introduced to Azure IaaS VM backup</linkText><title></title> in the Azure Backup documentation.

trans-unit.source: It covers the essentials about why you should backup your VM, prerequisites, and limitations.
trans-unit.target: It covers the essentials about why you should backup your VM, prerequisites, and limitations.

trans-unit.source: In order to use PowerShell effectively, it is necessary to understand the hierarchy of objects and from where to start.
trans-unit.target: In order to use PowerShell effectively, it is necessary to understand the hierarchy of objects and from where to start.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Object hierarchy</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Object hierarchy</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The 2 most important flows are enabling protection for a VM, and restoring data from a recovery point.
trans-unit.target: The 2 most important flows are enabling protection for a VM, and restoring data from a recovery point.

trans-unit.source: The focus of this article is to help you become adept at working with the PowerShell commandlets to enable these two scenarios.
trans-unit.target: The focus of this article is to help you become adept at working with the PowerShell commandlets to enable these two scenarios.

trans-unit.source: To begin, enable the Azure Backup commandlets by switching to AzureResourceManager mode by using the Switch-AzureMode commandlet:
trans-unit.target: To begin, enable the Azure Backup commandlets by switching to AzureResourceManager mode by using the Switch-AzureMode commandlet:

trans-unit.source: The following setup and registration tasks can be automated with PowerShell:
trans-unit.target: The following setup and registration tasks can be automated with PowerShell:

trans-unit.source: Create a backup vault
trans-unit.target: Create a backup vault

trans-unit.source: Registering the VMs with the Azure Backup service
trans-unit.target: Registering the VMs with the Azure Backup service

trans-unit.source: For customers using Azure Backup for the first time, you need to register the Azure Backup provider to be used with your subscription.
trans-unit.target: For customers using Azure Backup for the first time, you need to register the Azure Backup provider to be used with your subscription.

trans-unit.source: This can be done by running the following command: Register-AzureProvider -ProviderNamespace "Microsoft.Backup"
trans-unit.target: This can be done by running the following command: Register-AzureProvider -ProviderNamespace "Microsoft.Backup"

trans-unit.source: You can create a new backup vault using the New-AzureRMBackupVault commandlet.
trans-unit.target: You can create a new backup vault using the New-AzureRMBackupVault commandlet.

trans-unit.source: The backup vault is an ARM resource, so you need to place it within a Resource Group.
trans-unit.target: The backup vault is an ARM resource, so you need to place it within a Resource Group.

trans-unit.source: In an elevated Azure PowerShell console, run the following commands:
trans-unit.target: In an elevated Azure PowerShell console, run the following commands:

trans-unit.source: You can get a list of all the backup vaults in a given subscription using the Get-AzureRMBackupVault commandlet.
trans-unit.target: You can get a list of all the backup vaults in a given subscription using the Get-AzureRMBackupVault commandlet.

trans-unit.source: It is convenient to store the backup vault object into a variable.
trans-unit.target: It is convenient to store the backup vault object into a variable.

trans-unit.source: The vault object is needed as an input for many Azure Backup commandlets.
trans-unit.target: The vault object is needed as an input for many Azure Backup commandlets.

trans-unit.source: The first step towards configuring backup with Azure Backup is to register your machine or VM with an Azure Backup vault.
trans-unit.target: The first step towards configuring backup with Azure Backup is to register your machine or VM with an Azure Backup vault.

trans-unit.source: The Register-AzureRMBackupContainer commandlet takes the input information of an Azure IaaS virtual machine and registers it with the specified vault.
trans-unit.target: The Register-AzureRMBackupContainer commandlet takes the input information of an Azure IaaS virtual machine and registers it with the specified vault.

trans-unit.source: The register operation associates the Azure virtual machine with the backup vault and tracks the VM through the backup lifecycle.
trans-unit.target: The register operation associates the Azure virtual machine with the backup vault and tracks the VM through the backup lifecycle.

trans-unit.source: Registering your VM with the Azure Backup service creates a top-level container object.
trans-unit.target: Registering your VM with the Azure Backup service creates a top-level container object.

trans-unit.source: A container typically contains multiple items that can be backed up, but in the case of VMs there will be only one backup item for the container.
trans-unit.target: A container typically contains multiple items that can be backed up, but in the case of VMs there will be only one backup item for the container.

trans-unit.source: It is not mandatory to create a new protection policy to start backup of your VMs.
trans-unit.target: It is not mandatory to create a new protection policy to start backup of your VMs.

trans-unit.source: The vault comes with a 'Default Policy' that can be used to quickly enable protection, and then edited later with the right details.
trans-unit.target: The vault comes with a 'Default Policy' that can be used to quickly enable protection, and then edited later with the right details.

trans-unit.source: You can get a list of the policies available in the vault by using the Get-AzureRMBackupProtectionPolicy commandlet:
trans-unit.target: You can get a list of the policies available in the vault by using the Get-AzureRMBackupProtectionPolicy commandlet:

trans-unit.source: A backup policy is associated with at least one retention policy.
trans-unit.target: A backup policy is associated with at least one retention policy.

trans-unit.source: The retention policy defines how long a recovery point is kept with Azure Backup.
trans-unit.target: The retention policy defines how long a recovery point is kept with Azure Backup.

trans-unit.source: The New-AzureRMBackupRetentionPolicy commandlet creates PowerShell objects that hold retention policy information.
trans-unit.target: The New-AzureRMBackupRetentionPolicy commandlet creates PowerShell objects that hold retention policy information.

trans-unit.source: These retention policy objects are used as inputs to the New-AzureRMBackupProtectionPolicy commandlet, or directly with the Enable-AzureRMBackupProtection commandlet.
trans-unit.target: These retention policy objects are used as inputs to the New-AzureRMBackupProtectionPolicy commandlet, or directly with the Enable-AzureRMBackupProtection commandlet.

trans-unit.source: A backup policy defines when and how often the backup of an item is done.
trans-unit.target: A backup policy defines when and how often the backup of an item is done.

trans-unit.source: The New-AzureRMBackupProtectionPolicy commandlet creates a PowerShell object that holds backup policy information.
trans-unit.target: The New-AzureRMBackupProtectionPolicy commandlet creates a PowerShell object that holds backup policy information.

trans-unit.source: The backup policy is used as an input to the Enable-AzureRMBackupProtection commandlet.
trans-unit.target: The backup policy is used as an input to the Enable-AzureRMBackupProtection commandlet.

trans-unit.source: Enabling protection involves two objects - the Item and the Policy, and both need to belong to the same vault.
trans-unit.target: Enabling protection involves two objects - the Item and the Policy, and both need to belong to the same vault.

trans-unit.source: Once the policy has been associated with the item, the backup workflow will kick in at the defined schedule.
trans-unit.target: Once the policy has been associated with the item, the backup workflow will kick in at the defined schedule.

trans-unit.source: The backup schedule will take care of doing the full initial copy for the item and the incremental copy for the subsequent backups.
trans-unit.target: The backup schedule will take care of doing the full initial copy for the item and the incremental copy for the subsequent backups.

trans-unit.source: However, if you want to force the initial backup to happen at a certain time or even immediately then use the Backup-AzureRMBackupItem commandlet:
trans-unit.target: However, if you want to force the initial backup to happen at a certain time or even immediately then use the Backup-AzureRMBackupItem commandlet:

trans-unit.source: Most long running operations in Azure Backup are modelled as a job.
trans-unit.target: Most long running operations in Azure Backup are modelled as a job.

trans-unit.source: This makes it easy to track progress without having to keep the Azure portal open at all times.
trans-unit.target: This makes it easy to track progress without having to keep the Azure portal open at all times.

trans-unit.source: To get the latest status of an in-progress job, use the Get-AzureRMBackupJob commandlet.
trans-unit.target: To get the latest status of an in-progress job, use the Get-AzureRMBackupJob commandlet.

trans-unit.source: Instead of polling these jobs for completion - which is unnecessary, additional code - it is simpler to use the Wait-AzureRMBackupJob commandlet.
trans-unit.target: Instead of polling these jobs for completion - which is unnecessary, additional code - it is simpler to use the Wait-AzureRMBackupJob commandlet.

trans-unit.source: When used in a script, the commandlet will pause the execution until either the job completes or the specified timeout value is reached.
trans-unit.target: When used in a script, the commandlet will pause the execution until either the job completes or the specified timeout value is reached.

trans-unit.source: In order to restore backup data, you need to identify the backed-up Item and the Recovery Point that holds the point-in-time data.
trans-unit.target: In order to restore backup data, you need to identify the backed-up Item and the Recovery Point that holds the point-in-time data.

trans-unit.source: This information is supplied to the Restore-AzureRMBackupItem commandlet to initiate a restore of data from the vault to the customer's account.
trans-unit.target: This information is supplied to the Restore-AzureRMBackupItem commandlet to initiate a restore of data from the vault to the customer's account.

trans-unit.source: To get the PowerShell object that identifies the right backup Item, you need to start from the Container in the vault, and work your way down object hierarchy.
trans-unit.target: To get the PowerShell object that identifies the right backup Item, you need to start from the Container in the vault, and work your way down object hierarchy.

trans-unit.source: To select the container that represents the VM, use the Get-AzureRMBackupContainer commandlet and pipe that to the Get-AzureRMBackupItem commandlet.
trans-unit.target: To select the container that represents the VM, use the Get-AzureRMBackupContainer commandlet and pipe that to the Get-AzureRMBackupItem commandlet.

trans-unit.source: You can now list all the recovery points for the backup item using the Get-AzureRMBackupRecoveryPoint commandlet, and choose the recovery point to restore.
trans-unit.target: You can now list all the recovery points for the backup item using the Get-AzureRMBackupRecoveryPoint commandlet, and choose the recovery point to restore.

trans-unit.source: Typically users pick the most recent AppConsistent point in the list.
trans-unit.target: Typically users pick the most recent AppConsistent point in the list.

trans-unit.source: There is a key difference between the restore operations done through the Azure portal and through Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: There is a key difference between the restore operations done through the Azure portal and through Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: With PowerShell, the restore operation stops at restoring the disks and config information from the recovery point.
trans-unit.target: With PowerShell, the restore operation stops at restoring the disks and config information from the recovery point.

trans-unit.source: It does not create a virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: It does not create a virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: The Restore-AzureRMBackupItem does not create a VM.
trans-unit.target: The Restore-AzureRMBackupItem does not create a VM.

trans-unit.source: It only restores the disks to the specified storage account.
trans-unit.target: It only restores the disks to the specified storage account.

trans-unit.source: This is not the same behaviour you will experience in the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: This is not the same behaviour you will experience in the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: You can get the details of the restore operation using the Get-AzureRMBackupJobDetails commandlet once the Restore job has completed.
trans-unit.target: You can get the details of the restore operation using the Get-AzureRMBackupJobDetails commandlet once the Restore job has completed.

trans-unit.source: The ErrorDetails property will have the information needed to rebuild the VM.
trans-unit.target: The ErrorDetails property will have the information needed to rebuild the VM.

trans-unit.source: Building the VM out of the restored disks can be done using the older Azure ServiceManager PowerShell commandlets, the new Azure ResourceManager templates, or even using the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: Building the VM out of the restored disks can be done using the older Azure ServiceManager PowerShell commandlets, the new Azure ResourceManager templates, or even using the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: In a quick example, we will show how to get there using the Azure ServiceManager commandlets.
trans-unit.target: In a quick example, we will show how to get there using the Azure ServiceManager commandlets.

trans-unit.source: For more information on how to build a VM from the restored disks, read about the following commandlets:
trans-unit.target: For more information on how to build a VM from the restored disks, read about the following commandlets:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add-AzureDisk</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add-AzureDisk</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New-AzureVMConfig</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New-AzureVMConfig</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New-AzureVM</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New-AzureVM</linkText><title></title>
